This report was prepared by a team consisting of Staffan Synnerstrom (team leader), and

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Indonesia has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide advisory technical assistance (TA) to strengthen the capacity of the Commission for 
Eradication of Corruption (KPK) and implement this TA through the Partnership for Governance 
Reform in Indonesia. An ADB fact-finding mission undertook discussions with representatives of 
the Government of Indonesia during November 2003 on the proposed TA to strengthen KPK’s 
capacity after its establishment. As KPK was established in late December 2003 the Mission 
resumed the discussions in February 2004 with the newly appointed KPK Commissioners. The 
Mission reached an understanding with the Government on the TA’s purpose, scope, and 
implementation arrangements. The Mission also held consultations with civil society groups’ 
representatives. The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1. The TA is included in the 2004 
Indonesia country program.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy2  provides  increased  focus  on  supporting  anticorruption 
efforts as part of ADB’s broader emphasis on good governance and capacity building. The 
Country Strategy and Program for Indonesia3 recognizes good governance as a central pillar of 
ADB’s  assistance  to  the  country  and  defines  several  areas  for  anticorruption  initiatives, 
particularly in the context of decentralization. These areas are support for general anticorruption 
efforts such as audit reform and continued support for procurement reform; support to the 
Partnership for Governance Reform in Indonesia; and introduction of effective anticorruption 
mechanisms in ADB-funded projects. The country strategy and program in this respect reflects 
the  Government’s  own  identification  of  the  supremacy  of  law  and  good  governance  as  a 
national development priority within the national development plan (Propenas) 2000–2004. The 
KPK will be in need of support for a much longer period than the life span of this TA, and ADB 
may thus consider further support subject to the successful outcome of this TA, based on the 
Government’s requests and close coordination with other international funding agencies active 
in Indonesia. 
 
3.  Three important laws in support of a general process of combating corruption have been 
enacted since 1999, including Law 31/1999 on Eradication of Criminal Acts of Corruption, Law 
15/2002  on  Eradication  of  Money  Laundering,  and  Law  30/2002  on  the  Commission  for 
Eradication of Corruption. Important institutional development has also taken place, with a range 
of  state  auxiliary  bodies  established  with  mandates  that  contribute  to  the  fight  against 
corruption. These bodies include the Commission for the Audit of the Wealth of State Officials 
(KPKPN),  which  will  merge  with  KPK;  National  Ombudsman  Commission;  National  Law 
Commission; and Commission for the Eradication of Money Laundering. KPK will thus form a 
critical part of and become a focal point for a comprehensive institutional framework for tackling 
corruption in Indonesia. 
 
4.  Law 31/1999 provides for KPK’s establishment. Law 30/2002 sets out KPK’s institutional 
design and legal jurisdictions and elaborates on the preparations and procedures necessary for 
its  establishment.  According  to  Article  6  of  Law  30/2002,  KPK’s  responsibilities  include  (i) 
coordinating  with  and  supervising  agencies  having  authority  to  eradicate  corruption;  (ii) 
conducting investigations, interrogations, and prosecutions in connection with corruption; (iii)

taking steps to prevent corruption; and (iv) monitoring the functioning of state institutions. Article 
11  of  the  law  states  that  KPK  is  authorized  to  conduct  examinations,  investigations,  and 
prosecutions for corruption cases that (i) involve law enforcement officials, judiciary personnel, 
state officials, and any third party related to alleged corrupt activity committed by such officials; 
(ii) provoke public anxiety; and (iii) involve a minimum state loss of Rp1 billion.  
 
5.  KPK  will  have  four  divisions:  (i)  Prevention  Division,  (ii)  Prosecution  Division,  (iii) 
Information and Data Division, and (iv) Internal Supervisory and Public Complaint Division. 
KPK’s mandate covers Indonesia nationwide. While KPK will be headquartered in Jakarta, KPK 
may  also  form  offices  in  the  provinces.  Five  commissioners,  of  which  one  is  elected 
chairperson, will collectively lead KPK with a four member advisory team and executive staff. 
KPKPN will merge with KPK and serve as KPK’s Prevention Division.  
 
6.  KPK has a huge mandate, in terms of responsibilities and geographic spread. Many 
different kinds of tasks, requiring a variety of staff skills and operating procedures, will be 
performed, and all tasks must comply with the rule of law. Although Law 31/1999 spells out 
KPK’s main procedures, much work must go into developing operating procedures and into 
deciding how the various divisions and their tasks should interrelate with each other. This 
should be done at the outset.  
 
7.  Anticorruption efforts are particularly important in the context of the decentralization of 
responsibilities  within  most  government  sectors  that  took  place  in  2001.  Today,  district4 
governments are responsible for major public functions, including education and health and 
urban or rural development. However, in most cases, regional governments’ capacities to deal 
with their new responsibilities are low, and safeguards to prevent corruption are not in place. 
Within this context, KPK will assume a crucial role in spearheading a strategy for tackling 
corruption that brings together credible initiatives already started across Indonesia, through a 
road map. This will be an important initial task for KPK. 
 
8.  According to Article 9 of Law 30/2002, KPK shall in the future be able to take over from 
police officers and public prosecutors corruption cases that meet the criteria defined in the law. 
The law even stipulates in its transitional provisions that KPK shall take over ongoing cases 
from these individuals. These provisions do not necessarily coincide with regulations governing 
other authorities. How to develop legal and practical arrangements for the transfer of cases in a 
way that will be accepted by all involved institutions will be a delicate task that KPK will have to 
deal with at an early stage. Other provisions in Law 30/2002 also may conflict with provisions in 
other legislation. For example, KPK is empowered to request certain information from state 
institutions, but there seem not to be any corresponding provisions obliging these institutions to 
disclose the information requested. Similarly, the law authorizes KPK to request the suspension 
of a state official involved in a corruption case. But as long as higher officials continue to be 
protected from investigation and prosecution under civil service regulations, such provisions will 
turn out to be void in practice. These kinds of regulatory conflicts in Law 30/2002 merit an 
analysis that would lead to proposals on how to harmonize other laws with Law 30/2002.  
 
9.  The Partnership for Governance Reform in Indonesia, which is described in more detail 
in Appendix 4, has anticorruption as a main focus for its work and is heavily involved in 
supporting the preparations for the establishment of KPK. The Partnership for Governance 
Reform in Indonesia now runs a program to support KPK that includes, among other things,

support for selection and recruitment of staff members, support to develop a KPK strategy, and 
support  for  KPK  strategy  consultations  throughout  the  country.  As  this  TA  will  closely 
complement the support program, the TA’s being implemented through the Partnership for 
Governance Reform in Indonesia is highly justified.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The goal of the TA is to improve governance by reducing corruption in Indonesia’s 
society, through KPK’s performing effectively and in accordance with standards of successful 
commissions in other countries. The immediate objective is to help KPK become appropriately 
prepared  and  equipped  to  prevent  corruption  cases  and  carry  out  related  investigations, 
interrogations, and prosecutions; supervise other agencies; and monitor corruption in society. 
The TA will assist KPK by (i) supporting the development and introduction of KPK’s standard 
operating procedures (SOP), (ii) helping develop cooperation arrangements with police and 
public  prosecutors,  (iii)  procuring  and  installing  relevant  supporting  information  and 
communications technology (ICT) equipment, (iv) assessing training needs and designing and 
implementing initially relevant training programs for KPK’s staff, and (v) designing external 
dissemination activities necessary to make KPK’s role understood in society. In several of these 
areas of assistance this TA is a follow-up to TA 3381-INO Establishment of an Anticorruption 
Commission.5 The many important outputs from that TA will be used under this TA. 
 
11.  The inception report will be submitted within 1 month after commencement. The report 
will include an outline work program for the TA and any apparent or likely barriers that would 
prevent the TA’s successful outcome. The report will also make detailed recommendations 
concerning the types of ICT equipment to procure under the TA, considering KPK’s needs and 
the TA’s budget. The interim report will be submitted at the end of September 2004, upon 
completion of the draft SOPs and upon the completion of the training program’s design and the 
start of its implementation. The draft final report will be submitted 3 weeks before the TA’s 
completion. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.   The TA will help develop SOPs for KPK. Moreover, the TA will help review relevant 
legislation guiding KPK’s operations and performance, as a basis for developing SOPs, taking 
into account rule of law requirements; procedures defined in Law 31/1999; and KPK’s need to 
act efficiently in each case and effectively cooperate and coordinate with other agencies, within 
a limited period of time, as this will also provide a basis for developing SOPs. Provisions in Law 
30/2002 and in Law 31/1999 that conflict with other legislation should be identified, and ways to 
solve regulatory conflicts should be proposed. SOPs should support the human resources 
management  system  developed  by  KPK  and  include  appropriate  human  resources 
management  procedures. 
 
13.  If KPK is to perform successfully, a training needs assessment of KPK’s staff members 
is required, followed by the design and implementation of training programs for the entire staff. 
These activities will give commissioners and relevant staff members exposure to international

best practices, including other countries’ experiences with similar anticorruption commissions. 
Training programs will be designed in ways that KPK can use them after the completion of this 
TA. 
 
14.  To assist KPK in becoming fully operational in its four divisions, ICT equipment will be 
provided. KPK needs a secure database and ICT support to manage and monitor its operations. 
 
15.  Acceptance of KPK’s mandate and public support for its role will require strategies 
development  and  activities  implementation  designed  to  create  understanding  among  state 
institutions, private enterprises, civil society organizations, and concerned individuals on what 
constitutes corruption and how KPK is tasked to fight this. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $315,000 equivalent, comprising $150,000 in 
foreign currency cost and $165,000 equivalent in local currency cost. ADB will provide $250,000 
equivalent to finance $150,000 of the foreign currency cost and $100,000 equivalent of local 
currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the TASF. The Government, 
through KPK, will provide offices and staff to finance the balance of the local currency cost 
equivalent to $65,000. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan for the TA are shown in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  KPK  is  the  Executing  Agency.  The  Government  has  requested  the  Partnership  for 
Governance Reform in Indonesia to act as the Implementing Agency. The Partnership will 
appoint, at its expense, a TA project manager. Procurement under the TA will be made by the 
consultants, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Establishing a steering 
committee that will meet regularly (at least quarterly) to monitor progress is recommended. This 
committee, chaired by KPK, will include ADB and Partnership representatives. 
 
18.  KPK will contribute by providing office space and counterpart staff members for the TA 
team.  KPK  should  provide  (i)  air-conditioned  offices  for  the  TA  team  and  (ii)  sufficient 
administrative support, including support staff members. 
 
19.  Approximately 26 person-months of consulting services will be required over a period of 
9 calendar months, commencing in June 2004 and ending in March 2005. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants is given in Appendix 3. The input is estimated to be 7 person-months 
for the international consultant and 19 person-months for domestic consultants. The consultants 
will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  Since  the 
Partnership  for  Governance  Reform  in  Indonesia  will  provide  a  project  manager,  the 
international consultant would not need to be team leader or always in place. 
 
20.   Meetings  involving  the  consultant  team,  Partnership  for  Governance  Reform  in 
Indonesia, KPK, and ADB will be held 2 weeks after the submission of the inception report, the 
interim report, and the draft final report. Simplified progress reports will be submitted each week, 
in conjunction with weekly progress meetings involving the consultant team, Partnership, and 
KPK.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for Strengthening the Capacity of the Commission for Eradication 
of Corruption in Indonesia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
 
A.      Consultants 
1.  A team of qualified and experienced individual consultants, comprising one international 
and three domestic consultants will be recruited in accordance with the Asian Development 
Bank’s  (ADB’s)  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  The  expertise  required  of  the 
international  consultant  will  include  anticorruption  legislation;  anticorruption  institutions, 
especially how successful anticorruption commissions in other countries operate; anticorruption-
related  training;  business  processes  and  standard  operating  procedures  development;  and 
project management. Knowledge of Indonesian public administration and anticorruption efforts 
will  be  regarded  as  an  advantage.  The  international  consultant  will  work  in  a  team  with 
Indonesian consultants. By adopting a team approach, the international consultant will provide 
expertise in internationally accepted good practices, while the domestic consultants will provide 
local knowledge. 
 
B.  Requirements 
1.  International Consultant (7 person-months)  
2.  One international consultant will be engaged in two blocks, totaling 7 person-months, 
during the duration of the technical assistance (TA). The international consultant will have 
experience as an anticorruption commissioner or in establishing anticorruption commissions or 
as a judge, investigator, or prosecutor. The consultant should have experience in anticorruption 
strategies  and  their  dissemination,  anticorruption  legislation,  operating  procedures  for 
anticorruption  institutions  or  for  other  law  enforcement  institutions,  anticorruption-related 
training,  and  project  management.  The  consultant  should  be  knowledgeable  about  the 
responsibilities of Komisi Pemberantasan Korupsi (KPK), which are prevention, investigation, 
interrogation, and prosecution. 
 
3.  The international consultant’s having working experience related to anticorruption and 
antifraud  efforts  in  the  region—particularly  from  areas  where  anticorruption  efforts  were 
successfully implemented, such as Hong Kong, China; Republic of Korea; Singapore; and 
Thailand—will be an advantage. The international consultant’s speaking and reading Bahasa 
Indonesia will also be an advantage. 
 
2.  Domestic Consultants (19 person-months)   
4.  Three domestic consultants will be required to (i) know Indonesian procedures and 
practices  for  investigation,  interrogation,  and  prosecution;  (ii)  have  experience  in  business 
processes and workflows and standard operating procedures (SOPs) development; (iii) have 
substantial information and communication technology (ICT) knowledge, including database 
knowledge; and (iv) be familiar with working with public sector agencies in general and law 
enforcement agencies in particular. The following types of domestic consultants will be hired for 
the following numbers of person-months: 
 
(i)  A  criminal  justice  specialist  with  experience  in  investigating  or  prosecuting 
corruption or economic crime cases will be hired for a period of 5 person-months.

(ii)  A system analysis expert with experience in reviewing business processes and 
workflows and developing and designing SOPs will be hired for a period of 9 
person-months. 
 
(iii)  An ICT specialist with experience in assessing ICT equipment, procuring and 
installing needs and developing databases will be hired for a period of 5 person-
months. 
 
5.  All domestic consultants should have documented training experience in their respective 
fields of expertise and excellent verbal and written communication skills. 
 
C.  Main Tasks of the Consultant Team  
 
6.  The consultant team will perform the following tasks, with the international and domestic 
consultants working together in close cooperation with the Partnership for Governance Reform 
in Indonesia and KPK counterparts: 
 
(i)  Recommend and, after ADB, KPK, and Partnership approval, procure and install 
ICT facilities that should be procured for KPK during the early stages of the TA, 
taking KPK’s existing ICT facilities into account. 
(ii)  Review legislation to which KPK operations are subject, together with legislation 
governing  other  law  enforcement  agencies,  to  identify  inconsistencies  and 
conflicts that prevent KPK from effectively fulfilling its mandate. 
(iii)  Develop business processes and help prepare SOPs for KPK; help draft KPK 
regulations, to implement procedures and guide KPK’s cooperation with other 
law enforcement agencies; and help develop procedures for human resources 
management. 
(iv)  Assess KPK staff member training needs and design and implement relevant 
training programs for the managers and executives of KPK’s four divisions.  
(v)  Provide  in  a  timely  manner  specified  TA  reports,  which  will  be  reviewed  at 
meetings and revised as required, to KPK, Partnership, and ADB.  
(vi)  Provide  in  a  timely  manner  specified  outputs,  such  as  SOP  and  training 
programs, to KPK, Partnership, and ADB for approval.  
(vii)  Liaise  with  the  Partnership’s  project  manager  and  KPK  on  all  issues  of 
importance, to ensure timely establishment of office facilities and administrative 
support, including TA support staff members. 
(viii)  Report on the TA’s overall accomplishments. 
 
7.  TA 3381-INO1 produced a number of outputs. Some of these supported the preparation 
of Law 30/2002, while others targeted the implementation phase of the law and making KPK 
operational  (i.e.,  supporting  the  objective  of  this  TA).  TA  3381-INO  comprised  three 
components: (i) public dissemination and consultation on the nature and objectives of the 
commission and the corruption law, (ii) comparative studies of good practices for establishing 
and implementing the commission, and (iii) institutional design for the establishment of the 
commission. The reports resulting from components (ii) and (iii) provide essential guidance to 
this TA and should be used accordingly.

D.  Deliverables 
8.  The consultant team will prepare and submit for approval the following outputs: 
 
(i)  an  inception  report  within  1  month,  including  a  proposed  TA  work  program, 
detailed  recommendations  for  procurement  and  installation  of  KPK’s  ICT 
facilities, and analysis of any apparent or likely barriers (legal and others) that 
can prevent the TA’s intended accomplishments; 
(ii)  the SOPs, which should be submitted in English and Bahasa Indonesia, that will 
serve as a manual for all KPK operations; 
(iii)  the  draft  memorandums  of  understanding  on  cooperation  between  KPK  and 
other agencies; 
(iv)  a training program, including workshops, to assist KPK managers and executives 
in performing their tasks in an efficient way and in accordance with SOPs; 
(v)  an interim report, by the end of August 2004, upon the completion and design of 
the draft SOPs and upon the training program’s start of implementation, detailing 
the TA’s accomplishments to date; 
(vi)  a draft final report, 3 weeks prior to the TA’s completion, detailing and assessing 
accomplishments under the TA, including deliverables; and 
(vii)  the  final  report,  taking  into  account  KPK,  Partnership,  and  ADB  comments 
submitted at the TA’s completion. 
 
9.  The TA is expected to commence in June 2004 and be completed in March 2005.

Appendix 4  13 
THE PARTNERSHIP FOR GOVERNANCE REFORM IN INDONESIA 
 
 
1.    In  March  2000,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  joined  the  United  Nations 
Development Programme, World Bank, and other bilateral funding institutions in supporting the 
establishment of the Partnership for Governance Reform in Indonesia (the Partnership). The 
Partnership was established by a group of reform-minded Indonesians to be a platform for 
governance reform efforts supporting Indonesia’s transition toward democracy. The Partnership 
was designed to support Indonesian initiatives from committed people across society. 
 
2.    The Partnership’s unique approach reflects an emerging global consensus that reformed 
governance practices cannot be imposed from outside in a sustainable way. National ownership 
is the key to change. The Partnership has therefore been assigned to facilitate a coordinated 
and strategic approach to reform by bringing together key Indonesian government, civil society, 
and private sector stakeholders.  
 
3.  The  Partnership,  an  Indonesian  institution,  acts  on  behalf  of  the  Government.  The 
institution manages a $35 million trust fund provided on a grant basis from bilateral assistance 
sources, to support Indonesian governance reform initiatives. The Partnership also manages a 
facility to cover its operating costs and the costs of external activities that aim to engage 
stakeholders  or  prepare  for  projects  funded  under  the  trust  fund.  Partnership  funds  are 
registered in the state budget, and Partnership-funded projects are audited by the Supreme 
Audit Institution. The funds are administered by the Partnership on behalf of the National 
Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS)  under a memorandum of understanding. The 
Partnership has a governing board that advises on policy lines and other major issues. The 
governing board comprises Indonesian government officials (including the Minister of Finance 
and  the  BAPPENAS  chairperson),  Indonesian  civil  society  representatives,  and  major 
international  funding  agency  representatives.  ADB’s  Indonesia  Resident  Mission  country 
director sits on the governing board. An executive board comprising the Indonesian members of 
the  governing  board  leads  the  Partnership  and  decides on  strategic  issues  and  on  larger 
projects. A policy advisory committee reviews all executive director proposals to the board and 
provides the executive director with policy advice. ADB staff members sit on the policy advisory 
committee,  together  with  representatives  of  BAPPENAS,  United  Nations  Development 
Programme, and World Bank. 
 
4.  The Partnership’s vision is to extend and deepen the nature of cooperation between 
international funding agencies and Indonesia, in support of governance reform. The Partnership 
is recognized by the Government of Indonesia as having the authority to implement projects 
financed by foreign development assistance. The Partnership identified a number of priorities to 
be supported, which include developing anticorruption, decentralization, and legal and judicial 
expertise as well as civil service and police reform expertise. The Partnership has credibly 
operated in sensitive fields that remain difficult for international funding agencies to navigate, 
such as police reform and addressing political corruption. The Partnership recently engaged 
major  Indonesian  Muslim  organizations  to  fight  corruption,  and  the  Partnership  is  working 
closely with multiple government agencies at national and local levels. The organization has 
developed a unique niche in supporting reformers across Indonesia and can reach out in ways 
beyond those available to most international funding agencies.
